title.children: Big weed: Why marijuana users are worried corporations will replace drug dealers

image.altText: Empty classroom with several empty chairs and tables, set against large windows.

title.children: Not everyone agrees special schools should be phased out. But there's consensus about one thing

image.altText: Brett and Eddy wearing suits, looking serious, smoke behind them, holding violins.

items.synopsis: Brisbane violinists Brett Yang and Eddy Chen left coveted orchestra jobs to pursue YouTube stardom. This is how the duo built a social media audience of 7.5 million.

title.children: How two Brisbane violinists became global disruptors of classical music

image.altText: The woman's hands lie in her lap, she has pink nail polish and wears a leopard-print skirt.

title.children: This woman was choked by a man in a Canberra motel room. She says she wasn't given a fair trial

image.altText: The Australian women's rugby sevens team celebrates with the Oceania Rugby Sevens championship trophy

image.altText: Flames lap outside a window.

items.synopsis: A bushfire destroys at least two homes and forces two dozen people to shelter at a boat ramp overnight at the Tasmanian east coast community of Dolphin Sands.

title.children: Homes destroyed, locals shelter at boat ramp as bushfire hits Tasmanian beachside community

image.altText: ANZ

items.synopsis: Australian shares are set to post modest gains, despite a tech-led surge on Wall Street on Friday. ANZ posts a $7.1 billion profit, but with no growth on last year. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ANZ posts $7.1b profit, ASX set for modest gains despite Wall Street surge

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX futures turned negative late on before the actual market open, and that's carried over into early trading. In terms of index points, ANZ is the big drag, with the banking giant slumping 3.4% to $24.60 after a $7.1 billion profit result that clearly disappointed investors. ANZ's fall was leading a 0.7% decline across the financial sector. The other biggest loser on the ASX 200 is TPG Telecom, off 8.4% to $4.99 after the company pulled the plug on discussions with Vocus, which was looking to buy some of its enterprise, government and wholesale assets, including Vision Network. Unlike in the US, Australia's tech sector index was down 0.3%. Utilities, mining and energy were all in the black in early trade. Biggest gains: Elders +10% to $6.80 Boral +6.8% to $5.01 NIB Holdings +4.1% to $7.59 Light and Wonder +2.3% to $134.61 Incitec Pivot +2.2% to $2.965 Biggest losses: TPG Telecom -8.3% to $5 ANZ -3.3% to $24.635 Chalice Mining -2.8% to $1.59 Perseus Mining -2.6% to $1.695 Macquarie Group -2.5% to $158.62
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX opens lower as ANZ, TPG shares smashed

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: From David Chau down at the UBS annual conference. The Reserve Bank's former deputy governor Guy Debelle is spruiking the benefits of a speedier transition towards renewable energy in Australia. Dr Debelle has told an audience at the UBS Australasia Conference in Sydney that the nation's progess towards decarbonisation is still moving at a "slow pace" and has a "long way to go". He also says Australia has a comparative advantage -- over other nations -- which it is not taking full advantage of. By that, he means our access to sun and wind power (and the huge amounts of land to build those renewable energy plants). He says Australia has more than enough capacity to meet its own decarbonisation needs, while exporting that renewable energy to countries like Japan and South Korea. Despite the loss in fossil fuel revenues being "expensive", Dr Debelle said there is no other option than transition to renewables. "The alternative is a hell of a lot more expensive. So if we don't have a habitable planet, that's going to be pretty damn costly."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'If we don't have a habitable planet, that's going to be pretty damn costly': Debelle

children.content: From
David Chau down at the UBS annual conference
The
Reserve Bank's former deputy governor Guy Debelle
is spruiking the benefits of a speedier transition towards renewable energy in Australia.
Dr Debelle has told an audience at the
UBS Australasia Conference in Sydney
that the nation's progess towards decarbonisation is still moving at a "slow pace" and has a "long way to go".

He also says Australia has a comparative advantage -- over other nations -- which it is not taking full advantage of. By that, he means our access to sun and wind power (and the huge amounts of land to build those renewable energy plants).
He says Australia has more than enough capacity to meet its own decarbonisation needs, while exporting that renewable energy to countries like Japan and South Korea.
Despite the loss in fossil fuel revenues being "expensive", Dr Debelle said there is no other option than transition to renewables.
"The alternative is a hell of a lot more expensive. So if we don't have a habitable planet, that's going to be pretty damn costly."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Again showing how key sectors of the economy are reliant on IT infrastructure, thousands of containers have been stuck at ports due to a major cyber hack against DP World. The shadow home affairs and cyber security minister James Paterson told Sky News this morning that he had spoken to the port operator. "I was briefed by the company last night and they were hopeful that they would be able to restore normal operations in the next couple of days, and in the meantime what they are trying to do is build a parallel system that effectively allows the port to continue to operate, at least for those high-priority shipments in the meantime, so that doesn't have too adverse flow on consequences for our economy," he said. "My understanding from the company is that they detected suspicious and unauthorised activity on their own networks at about 10am on Friday, and they took a precautionary measure to shut down their networks or effectively disconnect them from the internet so that whatever was happening couldn't proceed any further." Mr Paterson said he understands the company did not receive a ransom note, either because the attack was successfully disrupted or because the attacker was motivated by something other than financial gain. If you're just getting up to speed with the issues, political reporter Georgia Roberts had this story yesterday.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: DP World still dealing with hacking, hoping to get back to normal in 'a couple of days'

featuredLink.title: Government says cyber incident that shut down Australia's second largest port operator 'serious and ongoing'

children.content: Again showing how key sectors of the economy are reliant on IT infrastructure, thousands of containers have been stuck at ports due to a
major cyber hack against DP World
The
shadow home affairs and cyber security minister James Paterson
told Sky News this morning that he had spoken to the port operator.
"I was briefed by the company last night and they were
hopeful that they would be able to restore normal operations in the next couple of days

, and in the meantime what they are trying to do is build a parallel system that effectively allows the port to continue to operate, at least for those high-priority shipments in the meantime, so that doesn't have too adverse flow on consequences for our economy," he said.

"My understanding from the company is that they detected suspicious and unauthorised activity on their own networks at about 10am on Friday, and they took a precautionary measure to shut down their networks or effectively disconnect them from the internet so that whatever was happening couldn't proceed any further."
Mr Paterson said he
understands the company did not receive a ransom note
, either because the attack was successfully disrupted or because the attacker was motivated by something other than financial gain.
If you're just getting up to speed with the issues,
political reporter Georgia Roberts
had this story yesterday.

image.altText: Two men in suits shaking hands, Parliament House and $100 notes in the background.

items.synopsis: Identified in Parliament House by their orange access passes, lobbyists are free to wander the halls, governed not by laws but by a code of conduct. But the standard of regulation in the industry has been deplored by both integrity experts and independent politicians.

image.altText: Saturn and its rings on a pitch black background.

items.synopsis: In the past few days, a slew of articles have run like wildfire through social media. Saturn's rings, those articles claim, are rapidly disappearing — and will be gone by 2025! So what's the story?

title.children: Could the next couple of months be our last chance to see Saturn's mighty rings?
